YUSU to reconsider Tokyo contract

04/03/2014

Welfare concerns have been raised after a club-goer was whipped with a leather belt at an official YUSU club night.

Image by

By undefined undefined

YUSU officials have indicated that they may end their contract with Tokyo after a club-goer was whipped with a leather belt as part of a game last Thursday during an official YUSU club night. According to a second year student who was present, a young man got up on stage and was whipped with the belt by two female members of the audience during the 'wheel of doom' game. The onlooker said that the act seemed "totally consensual" and the participant received a free bottle of champagne for his efforts. The student who was present at Tokyo on Thursday night told Nouse, "It was just club games really". This comes after Tokyo were criticised by YUSU for a game in which cream was put on a man's nipples and a female student licked it off. Kallum Taylor, YUSU President, commented: "Tokyo really aren't helping themselves with this kind of thing. This is the second incident we've had in the last few weeks, so you'd think it would be fresh in their minds to be more responsible. "Sadly now, this incident will be fresh in our minds come the tendering process later next term. Our arrangements have to be upheld - and no matter how good the night is, if we can't trust our partners, then we have a problem." The tendering process takes place in June, when a panel made up of the YUSU President, the Welfare Officer and YUSU staff decide which clubs are appropriate for sponsor. Clubs are invited to tell the panel how they will organise events and competitions and look after student welfare. Clubs must be in line with YUSU policy, particularly in terms of upholding welfare agreements, and show that they can produce "tasteful" publicity. Publicity for official events must be approved by YUSU at least five days before the event. One first year student shared YUSU's disapproval of the event, saying: "It's the kind of stunt that could make someone feel very uncomfortable in a club, especially on a student night out. The aim of YUSU club nights is to be inclusive and this could alienate people. "It's also degrading to the person involved. You can't be entirely sure that it was consensual given that he might not have felt comfortable refusing in front of a crowd." Another student disagreed however, explaining why they thought YUSU were overreacting: "I don't think it's a problem. When you go out on a student night you know what you're getting into. "Nobody makes you participate in anything you don't have to participate in, it's totally up to the individual. "If you volunteer to do something and decide you don't like it after then don't do it in future. It's ridiculous for YUSU to try and stop students from doing stuff like this. There's nothing wrong with a bit of kink after all." George Offer, YUSU Welfare Officer, said "'Consensual' doesn't necessarily mean safe, nor does it mean the student in question wasn't pressured into it. "Kallum is absolutely right that it's totally unacceptable to put students in such a situation; we made clear - following the recent whipped cream incident - that there are limits on what activity we can accept at a YUSU club night, and we will take adherence to these limits into account while tendering for next year's nights." Adele Lord, Regional Marketing and Events Manager of Tokyo, responded to the criticism, telling Nouse "The DJ has been sacked as a result of this activity and the Wheel of Doom has been removed from the entertainment schedule." Lord has previously apologised for similar events run at Tokyo in the past.
